speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 13-132, Riley v. California. Mr. Fisher?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Just -- just to test the principle for why the police can search and seize some -- some objects.  Consider a gun.  The arrestee has a gun on his person and the police take the gun.  Is part of the reason for that seizure to obtain evidence Alderson Reporting Company of the crime or is it just for the safety of the officer and the safety of the community?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about gathering evidence in order to make the case?  For instance, with the gun, could they take fingerprints?  The -- the gun is in the police station where the arrestee is being booked.  A, could they take fingerprints?  B, could they copy the serial number?  C, could they see how many shells were left in the chamber?  They obviously have to empty it for safety purposes.  All for the purpose of building the case, of -- of obtaining evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So -- so if -- if the proposition then, if the principle then is that some objects that are obtained from the arrestee can be examined in order to build the State's case, is that at least a beginning premise that we can accept in your Alderson Reporting Company case, although, obviously, there are problems of the extent and intrusiveness of the search that are -- are in your case, but not in the gun hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I think you're right that Gant is probably the best statement in support of the principle that I've -- I've suggested, and then you might say, well, that's limited to automobiles --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- and then we're back where we started.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Fisher, before we do that, have you been accurate in what you said about Robinson and about the Court's cases?  In Weeks, which was quoted in Robinson, the Court said:  "The right, always recognized under English and American law, to search the person of the accused when legally arrested to discover and seize the fruits or evidences of crime." Is that historically inaccurate?  Do you want us to repudiate that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did it say instrumentalities or evidence?  Which did it say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Because Justice Alito said evidence.  You -- you changed it to instrumentality.  Is one of you wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, smartphones -- smartphones do present difficult problems.  But let me ask you this:  Suppose your client were an old-school guy and he didn't have -- he didn't have a cell phone. He had a billfold and he had photos that were important to him in the billfold.  He had that at the time of arrest.  Do you dispute the proposition that the police could examine the photos in his billfold and use those as evidence against him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yes.  What is the difference between looking at hardcopy photos in a billfold and looking at photos that are saved in the memory of a cell phone?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, how does that apply -- how does that apply to these hardcopy photos in the billfold?  They don't present a threat to anybody.  And I don't see that there's much of a difference between -- the government argues there's a greater risk of the destruction of digital evidence in a cell phone than -- than there is in the photos.  So I don't quite understand how -- how that applies to that situation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but the -- but in the wallet -- we'll just stick with Justice Alito's hypothetical -- they find a business card or something which shows a car rental service.  Can they turn the card over and read it?  They're not looking for a pin or an explosive.  They're trying to read what's on the card.  Can they do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, they turn -- they turn the card over.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Including information that is specifically designed to be made public.  I mean, what about something like Facebook or a Twitter account?  There's no real -- there's no -- any privacy interest in a Facebook account is at least diminished because the point is you want these things to be public and seen widely.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So I guess my question would be:  Could you have a rule that the police are entitled to search those apps that, in fact, don't have an air of privacy about them?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: More -- more or less limited.  I mean, you know, maybe it's 20 people; maybe it's a hundred people.  But it's certainly not private in the sense that many of the other applications are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But do you think in this case we have to decide whether all the information that may be available in a smartphone can be examined by the Alderson Reporting Company police when the owner of the phone is arrested or can we just focus on the particular evidence that was admitted in your client's trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you think you could have obtained a warrant -- or that the police could have obtained a warrant in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then the evidence that's seizable under the warrant is -- is reasonable, and Justice Alito points out the fact that some of this evidence is -- is reasonable.  If there's a -- there's a Alderson Reporting Company limitation with reference to the way the police behaved, as Justice Alito points out, it's limited just to this evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but it -- it just goes to the fact that this -- that this is searchable under Fourth Amendment standards.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So how -- how would it work with a magistrate?  You recognize -- you just told Justice Kennedy -- that a warrant could be obtained.  A warrant for what?  What would the police have to show? And let's take your very case.  So they -- they have seized, which is proper, seized the phone, they've secured it, and now they want to search it.  So they apply for a warrant.  And what would the warrant have to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I thought you say that's very -- you've told us that that's -- that's hard to figure out, what you can and what you can't.  But it's easy for a magistrate, but -- but impossible for a -- for an arresting officer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If I could just --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- on the same lines as -- as Justice Scalia.  The point you make elsewhere in your brief and argument is that the cell phone or the -- the smartphone has everything.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's got the person's whole life.  Well, if you're arresting somebody on the grounds of suspicion that he's a gang member and you have evidence to support that, what part of the Alderson Reporting Company smartphone is not likely to have pertinent evidence? What application is not?  I mean, here you've got pictures, you've got videos, you've got calls.  I just -- I guess it's similar to what other issues have been raised.  I don't know what a magistrate is supposed to put in the warrant.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You don't think his banking app -- his banking app is going to say on this day he deposited $10,000 into his account, and then that's going to coincide with a particular drug deal.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if you have a device that doesn't have the broad information that a smartphone has, but only a very limited, like a Fitbit that tells you how many steps you've taken, and the defendant says, I've been in my house all afternoon, and they want to check and see if he's walked 4 miles.  It's not his whole life, which is a big part of your objection.  Is that something they can look at?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the phone in this case was an old-fashioned flip-phone?  So it had the capacity to take pictures, but a much more limited memory.  Would it -- would it be a different case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the person had on his person a compact disk with photos saved on that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Fisher, would you -- an earlier question, you didn't finish the answer.  You were describing a difference between the downloading by police into databases that they keep forever.  What happens with materials that are returned pursuant to a search warrant?  Are they precluded from doing that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I wasn't sure I understood your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  I don't know that you've answered my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Which -- can they do the same thing once a search warrant is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Frankly, I have to tell you, I don't ever remember a prosecutor coming to me with that kind of delineation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Fisher, would there be exigencies that would allow police to look at cell phones?  And if so, what would those exigencies be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand your first exigent circumstances.  When there is a bomb, but you can't -- you don't know whether there's a bomb until you look in the phone.  Whether -- whether his associates are on the way to, you know, to kill the officer and -- and release their confederate, you don't know until you look into the phone.  So how -- you know, how can that possibly be an exigent circumstance? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me it would almost never -- you would never be able to say, you know, surrounding circumstances give me reason to suspect that there's a bomb in the phone.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Give me reason to suspect that his confederates are on the way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There -- there is not much authority that I could find, if the lawyer is arrested and -- and they want to read his whole briefcase or you want to read a year's diary.  And you cite -- I think Alderson Reporting Company it's page 7 of your brief -- the Learned Hand 1916 case. Is that about the best discussion you -- you can find? I didn't find anything much different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because it's important if we're going to try to formulate some standard which limits the extent of the search, and that's one of -- that's one of the problems in this case.  If -- if say we rule for the government in its case, maybe it's not quite fair to ask you, but if we rule for the government in its case in Wurie, for the Federal case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- and there's no -- it's not an exigent circumstances, is there some standard where we could draw the line which would still result in a judgment in -- in your favor?  Maybe that's not quite a fair question.  You're not -- you're not answering -- you're not arguing the -- the government's case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm going to say something first.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If -- if the phone rings, can the police answer it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  A warrant for what?  A warrant for examining the phone?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For somebody's arrest. Well, how does that extend to your ability to answer his phone? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, including the criminals who are more dangerous, more sophisticated, more -- more elusive with cell phones.  That's the -- that's the other side of this.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is it significant in -- in this case that the information was not protected by a password?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That doesn't -- that doesn't affect the expectation of privacy?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No.  I know they argue that it doesn't matter, but I'm just wondering if your position is weakened by the fact that the individual did not seek the greater protection of a password.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Dumont.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, in one of our Court decisions in the past, a series of justices asked -- or noted that many of our rules were based on practical considerations.  Practically speaking, a person can only carry so much on their person.  That is different because carrying a billfold of photographs is a billfold of photographs.  It's, you know, anywhere from one to five generally and not much more.  But now we're talking about potentially thousands, because with digital cameras people take endless photos and it spans their entire life. You don't see a difference between the two things?  What -- what has now become impractical.  A GPS can follow people in a way that prior following by police officers in cars didn't permit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: By the way --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dumont, on your argument and on the government's -- the Solicitor General's principal argument, too, a person can be arrested for anything.  A person can be arrested for driving without a seat belt.  And the police could take that phone and could look at every single e-mail that person has written, including work e-mails, including e-mails to family members, very intimate communications, could look at all that person's bank records, could look at all that person's medical data, could look at that person's calendar, could look at that person's GPS and find out Alderson Reporting Company every place that person had been recently because that person was arrested for driving without a seat belt. Now, that strikes me as a very different kind of world than the kind of world that you were describing where somebody has pictures of their family in a billfold.  Doesn't it strike you that way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I don't know why this is a marginal case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Your argument and the Solicitor General's principal argument applies to any arrest.  And it applies to everything on a cell phone. People carry their entire lives on cell phones.  That's not a marginal case.  That's the world we live in, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The Court is to make a rule not for this particular case, but for this category of cases.  And I think what Justice Kagan pointed out is very nervous concern.  That is, take an offense like failing to buckle up, even driving under the influence, not gang crimes, which is what we have in this case. It's your rule, then, that the cell phone is fair game no matter what the crime, no matter how relatively unimportant the crime.  Is it all misdemeanors, all misdemeanors and that opens the world to the police.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Dumont, I guess what I'm trying to suggest to you is that you call it marginal, but, in fact, most people now do carry their lives on cell phones, and that will only grow every single year as, you know, young people take over the world. Alderson Reporting Company (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, that's not a marginal case.  That's what -- they're computers.  They have as much computing capacity as -- as laptops did five years ago.  And -- and everybody under a certain age, let's say under 40, has everything on them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you saying we're just resting on the discretion of the officer?  Because if that's so, then that leads to the next question.  Well, if that's so, then we'll get a warrant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, let's leave -- let's leave exigent circumstances out of it.  That -- that's an easy case.  You're not arguing for exigent circumstances here. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Have there ever been -- is there any basis for the generality that there's a safety concern?  Do you have a case where the -- certainly not where the phone exploded, but when the phone was used to trigger a device or anything like that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you have a general case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What does that have to do with my question about a bomb?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I would assume you need to operate the phone to set off the bomb, so that once the police have the phone the bomb is not going to be set off. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could I just ask you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could I ask you a question about the extent of your theory?  We're talking about smartphones, which are minicomputers.  But your theory would apply to iPads, computers, anything that's, for example, sitting next to a person in a car, at their desk if they are arrested at their desk, anywhere if they are carrying it in their hand because you see a lot of people carrying the iPad or something comparable, a tablet of some sort.  Your theory would permit a search of all of those things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, how would you? Alderson Reporting Company What is the rule?  You're saying on the person.  Suppose it's in the car in a holder or suppose it's in the passenger's seat?  Are you saying that's -- you don't want to express an opinion about that?  You only want to talk about what's in somebody's pocket?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, suppose I'm carrying my laptop in my backpack.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so whatâ€™s your rule? So there are three possibilities:  Possibility one, smartphone, no, get a warrant, unless exigent circumstances.  Possibility two, yes, it's just like a piece of paper that you find in his pocket.  Or possibility three, sometimes yes, sometimes no.  All right, which of those three is yours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, I mean of my three Alderson Reporting Company choices.  I mean, call the first choice never except exigent without a warrant; always, you don't need a warrant; or three, somewhere in between.  Which of the three choices is yours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In between.  Okay.  Now we're in between.  Then I get to my follow up question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My follow up question is, please tell me what your in-between rule is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand that, Mr. Dumont.  Everything --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dumont -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Justice Kagan has a question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dumont, I guess I just don't understand.  You said if it could be.  I mean, everything could be reduced to a piece of paper.  All your bank records, you could have them on you.  All your medical records, you could just happen to have them on you.  I mean, that would be so of absolutely everything, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I think that the notion that you could get them legally in some other way has never justified an illegal search otherwise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Your rule is sometimes.  So

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think he inverted two and three, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That gives you time to think.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So but that's a significant concession on your part, isn't it, because Alderson Reporting Company the smartphones carry a lot of information that would not have been the sort of thing police could look at before.  GPS tracking information, the police could never have gotten that before.  So you are saying that is protected?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me that in order to try to give some answer to Justice Kagan's concerns that maybe the distinction ought to be between serious and nonserious offenses -- offenses.  I don't think that exists in our jurisprudence.  Correct me if I'm wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: By the way, GPS information, I don't want to admit it, but my wife might put a little note in my pocket".  Steven, remember, turn right at the third stoplight, proceed three blocks forward.  Of course you could have looked at information that showed where you had been and where you were going as long as it was on paper.  Now it's in a GPS.  So how does your rule help?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The GPS would see if Alderson Reporting Company he did, in fact, turn right at the thing or had gone somewhere else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You could amend your answer and it's -- the answers are for you, not for us.  But you could amend your answer to say not just anything that somebody could have had.  The person could have had a diary that records every place the person has ever gone in the last year, it's theoretically possible.  But you could say something that has a realistic analogue in the predigital era.  We have a similar -- a problem here that's similar to the problem in the Jones GPS case. You have a rule of law that was established in the predigital era and now you have to apply it in the digital era or you're asked to apply it in the digital era where the technology changes a lot of things.  But if there is a close analogue in the digital era to something that would have been allowed in the predigital era, that may be a different story.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you're not willing to limit -- you're not willing to limit your position to searches that either are in order to protect the officer or in order to preserve evidence or, number three, in order to find evidence of the crime of arrest.  You're not willing to limit it that way?  You would say whatever is on the person, you can -- you can search.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that gets you into the arrest for, you know, for not wearing a seat belt, and it seems absurd that you should be able to search that person's iPhone. And you can avoid that if you -- if you say, look, in the vast majority of cases, this is not going to be a problem, unless the officer can reasonably be looking for evidence of the crime of arrest.  That will cover the bad cases, but it won't cover the -- you know, the seat belt arrest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or how -- there's an analogue with photos.  The arrested person has photos, pre-digital age.  Of course you can look at them.  On the phone there are photos.  Absolutely analogous, except there are 10,000.  It's indeed his entire life history in photos.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On your rule, can the policeman look at the photos by analogue or not, because there are 10,000.  Okay?  What's the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What we have is, by the way -- you understand where I'm going.  I think there are very, very few things that you cannot find in analogue to in pre-digital age searches.  And the problem in almost all instances is quantity and how far Alderson Reporting Company afield you're likely to be going.  Do I accept your rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dumont, is -- are you saying, essentially, that nobody has any expectation of privacy, or that somebody has a dramatically reduced expectation of privacy in anything that the person actually wants to keep on them at all times?  In other words, one has to keep one's cell phone at home to have an expectation of privacy in it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Dreeben?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But, Mr. Dreeben, if the -- the understanding was, when there's time, get a warrant.  So here, you can seize the phone and you can secure the phone, and you could go to a magistrate and within an hour get permission to search.  But what is the reason for cutting out the magistrate here?  It's not -- the instrument itself is not going to be in any danger because the police have taken it and they've disabled it.  So I don't understand why we cut the warrant out of this picture.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you have cases where that has happened?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We've had a couple of States where this has been so, where they've had a rule that you can't search, for Michigan, I think, and Vermont.  And are there any instance out of those States where these scenarios have taken place?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You don't know of any.  I take it you don't know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So isn't this a problem that might be postponed because we have warring technologies, et cetera?  And is it -- you're saying now we should allow searches of all cell phones because there might be a technology that hasn't yet in fact been used in any of the States that have this rule.  That sounds a little hypothetical.  I'm not quite sure how to handle it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How about putting -- let me stop you, because you were making that argument in your brief, and I have three related questions.  Okay? Why can't you just put the phone on airplane mode?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're -- you're confusing me, because if you haven't searched on the scene, then the wipe is going to happen.  If you've had enough time at the precinct to put it on airplane mode, the wipe hasn't happened.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm a little confused Alderson Reporting Company about what this argument is.  Either you do it at the scene and you protect the phone --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- or you do at the station, and you have enough time to get the warrant by putting it on airplane mode.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't disagree.  Put it on airplane mode.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I don't disagree with you, but you're asking us for constitutional principle based on technology that might or might not do something in one or more cases, but not in the general -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but that's not -- that's not quite accurate.  What would you do under the Robinson rule with an attorney's briefcase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and doesn't that present the exact problem that every cell phone has?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So I don't think that quite works for you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, the tax return that's on -- some -- some cell phones have tax returns, so you have the tax return of the jaywalker, looking for a crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I ask you a question Alderson Reporting Company about that, Mr. Dreeben, because given the variety of things that these cell phones have in them, it seems as though that's -- you know, it sounds good as a limiting principle, but it ends up you can imagine in every case that the police could really look at everything. So I'll give you an example.        It's sort of like this case.  Somebody is arrested for a gun crime and now we're going to look at all the various things that might be related to a gun crime.  So whether he's bought guns, whether -- you know, what -- what -- whether he's done searches for gun stores.  His e-mails might something say something about gun possession or gun purchase.  He might have photographs of him with a gun.  You know, the whole range of things could relate to that crime, couldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, they would be looking at the same things, but the whole idea of a warrant is that a neutral magistrate tells you that you can look at those things and has an opportunity to limit it in whatever way the neutral magistrate feels is appropriate --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- and that's a protection.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead, please.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. 4 minutes, Mr. Fisher.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
